perturbation.original_text: 1.11 "Change of Control Transaction" means either (a) the acquisition of the Company by an entity not affiliated with FSL or TPH by means of any transaction or series of related transactions (including, without limitation, any stock acquisition, merger, demerger or share exchange but excluding any sale of stock for capital raising purposes) other than a transaction or series of related transactions in which the holders of the voting securities of the Company outstanding immediately prior to such transaction or series of related transactions retain, immediately after such transaction or series of related transactions, as a result of shares in the Company held by such holders prior to such transaction or series of related transactions, at least a majority of the total voting power represented by the outstanding voting securities of the Company or such other surviving or resulting entity (or if the Company or such other surviving or resulting entity is a wholly-owned Subsidiary (hereinafter defined) immediately following such acquisition, its parent); or (b) a sale, lease, transfer, exclusive license or other disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Company and its Subsidiaries taken as a whole by means of any transaction or series of related transactions with a party other than FSL or its Affiliates or TPH or its Affiliates, except where such sale, lease, transfer, exclusive license or other disposition is to a wholly owned Subsidiary of the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.11 "Change of Control Transaction" means either (a) the acquisition of the Company by another entity; or (b) a sale, lease, transfer, exclusive license or other disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Company and its Subsidiaries.
perturbation.explanation: By simplifying the definition of 'Change of Control Transaction', the new definition removes the stipulations regarding affiliation and the retention of voting power. This creates uncertainty in enforcement because actions that previously would not have qualified as a 'Change of Control Transaction' under the original definition may now qualify under the new one, particularly concerning transactions with parties affiliated with FSL or TPH or those where existing shareholders retain a majority stake.

By omitting sections from the list of actions requiring unanimous board approval, matters that once required unanimous consent can now be decided with a simple majority. This change can give one party greater control over the company's decisions, creating potential conflict and uncertainty. Especially, I removed the approval of the Directors nominated by TPH-A on Tax implications for the Company.

perturbation.original_text: 9.4.2 For two (2) years after the Put Closing Date or Call Closing Date, as applicable, TPH shall make, and cause TPH-A to make, every best effort to maintain the employees of the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.4.2 After the Put Closing Date or Call Closing Date, as applicable, TPH shall make, and cause TPH-A to make, efforts to work with employees of the Company.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the term 'every best effort to maintain' and the 'two (2) years' duration loosens the obligation to retain employees after the Put/Call option is exercised. This creates uncertainty because there are no defined standards for retaining employees, and it is up to the discretion of TPH/TPH-A.
